instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message: Hello guys, have got <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> , the keyboard and trackpad works okay , however , when I connect them both , the machine would restart continuously, When I connect just the trackpad , it works , also when I connect just the keyboard it works , but both , the machine would constantly restart. After the machine is booted, if I connect the keyboard trackpad, the Mac will work okay , but will not boot with them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message:
Try another keyboard first.
Monitor <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal.
Keyboard signal go to PCH through trackpad circuitry.
You cannot discard KB, if TP flex is not connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message: tried another keyboard and trackpad plus cable , but still same thing, what should I look out for on the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message:
Disconnect TP flex, let only KB connected to MLB.
Then post <SIGNAL>I2C_IOXP_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA voltages pressing some keys.
Also post voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>I2C_IOXP_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA = 3.3V stable and <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. = stable at 3.42V


Would also add that the Mac only restart when its booting into the OS .. without OS the machine would not restart and the keyboard/trackpad works okay, its also not the drive nor the operating system

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>I2C_IOXP_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA = 3.3V stable"
One line should drop until 0.4V and other to 2.7V when you keep some keys pressed.
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> comes back steady high after pressing power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message: The <SIGNAL>I2C_IOXP_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA drops as you said  but that is when the machine is not booted, however for the machine to boot , I will have to disconnect either trackpad or keyboard and the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> goes back up , upon pressing the power button

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot loop when trackpad and keyboard are connected at the same time
threads.message:
Check PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> with both TP and KB connected.
Also try other TP flex and board.
New chinese TP flex can get problems, many crappies...
